titleStmt.author: Rowley, Samuel, d. 1633.

div.p: When you see me, You know me.
Or the famous Chronicle Historie of king Henry the eight, with the birth and vertuous life of Edward Prince of Wales.
As it was playd by the high and mightie Prince of Wales his seruants.
By SAMVELL ROWLY, seruant to the Prince.
LONDON, Imprinted for Nathaniell Butter, and are to be sold in Paules Church-yeard neare Saint Austines gate. 1605.

div.head: When you see me, You know me.
div.stage: Enter the Cardinall with the Embassadours of Fraunce, in all state and royaltie, the Purse and Mace before him.

sp.speaker: Woolsie.
sp.l: GEntlemen giue leaue: you great embassadors,
From Francis the most christian king of Fraunce:
My Lord of Paris, and Lord Boneuet,
Welcome to England: since the king your maistes
Intreates our furtherance to aduance his peace;
Giuing vs titles of high dignitie,
As next elect to Romes Suprenacie.
Tell him we haue so wrought with English Henry
(Who, as his right hand loues the Cardinall)
That vn-delaid, you shal haue audience:
And this day will the king in person sit
To heare your message, and to answere it.

sp.speaker: Boneuet.
sp.l: Your grace hath done vs double curtesie:
For so much doth the king our maister long,
To haue an answer of this embassage.
As minutes are thought months till we returne.

sp.speaker: Paris.
sp.l: And that is the cause his highnesse moues your grace,
To quicke dispatch betwixt the king and him:
And for a quittance of your forwardnesse,
And hopefull kindnesse to the crowne of Fraunce,
Twelue reuerent Bishops are sent post to Rome,
Both from his highnesse and the Emperour,
To moue Campeus and the Cardinals,
For your election to the papall throne,
That Woolsies head may yeare the tripall Crowne.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: We thanke his highnesse for remembring vs.
And so salute my Lord the Emperour,
Both which (if Woolsie be made Pope of Rome)
Shall be made famous through all Christendome.
How now Bonner.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Sir William Cumpton from his highnesse comes,
To do a message to your excellence,

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Delay him a while, and tell him we are busie,
Meane time my Lords you shall with draw your selues,
Our priuate conference must not be knowne,
Let all your gentlemen in their best array,
Attend you brauely to king Henries court,
Where we in person presently will meete you:
And doubt not wele preuaile succesfully.

sp.speaker: Bone.
sp.l: But hath your grace yet moued his highnes sister,
For kind acceptance of our Soueraignes loue.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: I haue, and by the kings meanes finisht it,
And yet it was a taske, I tell yee Lords,
That might haue bene imposed to Hercules,
To win a Lady of her spirit and yeares.
To see her first loue cround with siluer haires,
As old king Lewes is, that bedrid lyes,
Vnfit for loue, or worldly vanities.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: But tis is countries peace the king respects,

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.l: We thinke no lesse, & we haue fully wrought it,
The Emperours forces that were leuied,
To inuade the frontyres of loe Burgondy,
Are staid in Brabant by the kings commaund,
The Admirall Hayward that was lately sent,
With threescore saile of ships and pinnaces,
To Batter downe the townes in Normandy,
Is by our care for him, cald home againe:
Then doubt not of a faire successefull end;
Since Woolsie is esteemd your Soueraines friend.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: We thanke your excellence, and take our leaues,

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Hast ye to court, lie meete ye presently.

sp.speaker: Bone.
sp.l: God morrow to your grace.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.l: God morrow Lords, go cal Sir William Cumpton in,
We must haue narrow eyes, and quicke conceit,
To looke into these dangerous stratagemes,
I will effect for Fraunce, as they for me:
If Woolsie to the Popes high state attaine,
The league is kept, or else herebreakt againe,
Now good Sir William

sp.speaker: Cum.
sp.l: The king my Lord intreates your reuerent grace,
There may be had some priuate conference,
Betwixt his highnesse and your excellence,
Before he heare the French Embassadors,
And wils you hasten your repaire to him,

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: We will attend his highnesse presently,
Bonner, see all our traine be set in readinesse,
That in our state and pompe pontificiall,
We may passe on to grace king Henries court,

sp.speaker: Cump.
sp.l: I haue a message from the Queene my Lord,
Who much commends, & humbly thanks your grace,
For your exceeding loue, and zealous prayers,
By your directions through all England sent:
To inuocate for her sound prosperous helpe,
By heauens faire hand in child-bed passions.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: We thanke her highnesse that accepts our loue,
In all Cathedrall Churches through the land,
Are Masses, Derges, and Prosessions sung:
With prayers to heauen to blesse her Maiestie,
And send her ioy, and quicke deliuery:
And so Sir William do my duty to her,
Queene Iane was euer kind and courteous,
And alwaies of her subiects honoured.

sp.speaker: Cump.
sp.l: I take my leaue my Lord.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.l: Adew good knight weele follow presantly,
Now Woolsie worke thy wittes like gaddes of steele,
And make them plyable to all impressions,
That King and Queene and all may honour thee:
So toild not Caesar in the state of Roome,
As Woolsie labours in the affaires of Kings:
As Hanniball with oyle did melt the Alpes:
To make a passage into Italie:
So must we beare our high pitcht Eminence
To digge for glorie in the hearts of men.
Till we haue got the papall diadem:
And to this end haue I composd this plot,
And made a League betweene the French and vs
And match their Aged King in holy Mariage,
With Ladie Mary Royall Henries sister:
That he in peace complotting with the Emperor
May plead for vs within the Courts of Rome:
Wherefore was Alexanders fame so great,
But that he conquered and deposed Kings,
And where doth Woolsie faile to follow him,
That thus comman deth Kings and Emperors,
Great Englands Lord haue I so won with words:
That vnder culloure of aduising him,
I ouerrule both Counsell, Court, and King:
Let him command, but we will execute.
Making our glorie to out-shine his fame
Till we haue purchast an eternall name.
Now Boner, are those proclamations sente
As we directed to the Shriffes of London,
Of certaine new deuised Articles,
For ordering those brothelles called the Stewes?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: They are readie my Lord, and the Shrieue attends for them,

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.l: Dispatch him quickely, and haste after me;
We must attend the Kings high Maiestie.

div.stage: Sound Trumpets, Enter King Harry the Eight, Queene Iane bigge with Child, the Cardinall, Charles Brandon Duke of Suffolke, Dudlit, Graye, Compton, the Ladie Marie, The Countesse of Salisburie attending on the Queene.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Charles Brandon, Dudly, and my good Lord Gray,
Prepare your selues, and be in readinesse,
To entertaine these French Embassadors,
Meete them before our royall Pallace Gate:
And so conduct them to our Maiestie.
We meane this day to giue them Audience.

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.l: Gray, We will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: Le tone attend without.
And bring vs word when they are comming on:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How now Queene Iane (Mother of God) my loue
Thou wilt neuer be able to sit halfe this time:
Ladies, I feare shele wake ye, yer be long,
Me thinkes she beares her burthen verie heauily,
And yet good sister and my honored Lords,
If this faire houre exceede not her expect.
And passe the callender of her accounts,
Shee will heare this Embassage, Iane wilt thou nor

sp.speaker: Q: Iane,
sp.l: Yes my deere Lord, I cannot leaue your sight.
So long as life retaines this Mantion?
In whose sweete lookes bright soueraigntyes in Thronde,
That make all Nations loue and honor thee,
Within thy frame sits Awfull Maiestie,
Wrethed in the curled furrowes of thy fronte:
Admird and feard euen of thine enemies;
To be with thee, is my felicitie.
Not to behold the state of all the world,
Could winne thy Queene, thy sicke vnwildie Queene,
To leaue her Chamber, in this mothers state.
But sight of thee vnequall potent ate,

sp.speaker: Kyng.
sp.l: God a-mercie Iane, reach me thy princely hand.
Thou art now a right woman, goodly, cheife of thy sex;
Me thinkes thou art a Queene suparlatiue,
Mother, a God this is a womans glorie,
Like good September Vines loden with fruite.
How ill did they define the name of wemen,
Adding so soule a preposition:
To call it woe to man, tis woe from man.
If woe it be, and then who dus not know,
That weomen still from men receaue their woe.
Yes, hey loue men for it, but whats their gaine,
Poore soules no more but trauaile for their paine;
Come, loue thou art sad, call Will Sommers in, to
Make her merrie, where is the foole to day,

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.l: He was met my Leige they say at London
Earely this morning with Doctor Skelton,

sp.speaker: Ile.
sp.l: Hes neuer from him, goe let a grome be sent,
And fetch him home, my good Lord Cardinall:
Who are the cheife of these Embassadors?

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Lord Boneuet the French high Admirall,
And Iohn de Mazo reuerent Bishop of Paris.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let their welcome be thy care good Woolsie.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: It shall my Liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Spare for no cost, Compton, what newes?

sp.speaker: Cump.
sp.l: Embassadors my Liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Inough, go giue them entertainement Lords,
Charles Brandon, hearst thou, giue them courtesie
Inough, and state inough, go conduct them.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: I go my Lord.

div.stage: Enter Will sommers booted and spurved, blowing a horne.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: How now William, what? post, post, where haue you bene riding.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Out of my way old Hary, I am all on the spurre,
I can tell yee, I haue tidings worth telling.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why, where hast thou bin:

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Marrie I rise early, and ride post to London, to know what newes was here at Court.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Was that your neerest way William?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: O I, the verie foote pathe, but yet I rid the horse way to here it, I warrant there is nere a Cundhead keeper in London, but knowes what is done in all the Courts in Cristendome

sp.speaker: Wolsie.
sp.p: And what is the best newes there William?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Good newes for you my Lord Cardinall, for one of the old wemen Waterbearers told me for certain, that last Friday all the belles in Rome Rang backward, there was a thowsand Derges sung, sixe hundred auemaries said, euerie man washt his face in holy water, the people crossing and blessing themselues to send them a new Pope, for the old is gon to purgatory.

sp.speaker: Wolsie:
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Nay, my Lord you'd laugh, if't were so indeed, for euery bodie thinks if the Pope were dead; you gape for a benefice, but this newes my Lord is cald too good to be true.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: But this newes came a pace Will, that came from Rome to London since Friday last,

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: For, twas at Billings-gate by Satterday Morning, twas a full Moone, and it came vp in a spring tide.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Then you here of the Embassadors that are come.

sp.speaker: Wills.
sp.p: I, I, & that was the cause of my ryding to know what they came for, I was told it all at a Barbars.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Ha, ha, what a fooles this, Iane, and what doe they say he comes for, Will:

sp.speaker: William:
sp.p: Marry they say he comes to craue thy aide against the great Turk that vowes to ouerrunne all France within this fortnight, he's in a terrible rage belike, & they say, the reason is, his old god Mamet that was buried ith top on's Church at Meca, his Tombe fell downe, and kilde a Sowe and seuen Pigges, whereupon they thinke all swines flesh is new sanctified, and now it is thought the Iewes wil fall to eating of porke extreamely after it.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.p: This is strang indeede, but is this all.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
No there is other newes that was told me, among the wemen at a backe house, and that is this, they say, the great Bell in glassenberie. Tor has told twise, and that king Arthur, and his Knights of the round Table that were buried in Armour, are aliue again, crying Saint Gorge for England, and meane shortly to conquere Rome,
marrie this is thought to be but a morrall,

sp.speaker: king.
sp.p: The Embassadors are comming, and heare William see that you be silent, when you see them heare.

sp.speaker: William:
sp.p: Ile be wise and say little I warrant thee, and therefore till I see em come, Ile go talke with the Queene; how dost thou lane, sirra. Harrie, shee lookes verie bigge vpon me, but I care not, and shee bring thee a young Prince, Will sommers may hap's be his foole, when you two are both dead and rotten:

sp.speaker: Kin:
sp.l: Goe to William, how now Iane what groning,
Gods me th'hast an Angrie soldiers frowne:

sp.speaker: William.
sp.l: I thinke to Harrie, thou hast prest her often:
I am sure this two yeres she has seru'd vnder thy standard.

sp.speaker: Q: lane,
sp.l: Good faith my Lord I must intreat your grace
That with your fauour I may leaue the presence:
I cannot stay to heare this Embassage,

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Gods holy mother, Ladies leau her to her chamber,
Goe bid the Midwiues, and the Nursses v. aight,
Make hole some fiers and take her from the Ayer,
Now Iane God bring me but a chopping boy,
Be but the Mother to a Prince of Wales
Ad a ninth Henrie to the English Crowne,
And thou mak'st full my hopes, faire Queene adew:
And may heauens helping hand our ioyes renew:

sp.speaker: Comp:
sp.l: God make your Maiestie a happie Mother,

sp.speaker: Dud:
sp.l: And helpe you in your weakest passions,
With zealous prayer we all will inuocate:
The powers deuine for your deliuerie:

sp.speaker: Q: lane,
sp.l: We thanke you all, and in faire enterchange
We'l pray for you: now on my my humble knees,
I take my leaue of your high Maiestie,
God send your highnesse long and happie Raigne,
And blesse this kingdome, and your subiects lyues:
And to your gratious heart all ioy restore,
I feare I shall neuer behold you more,

sp.speaker: King,
sp.l: Doe not thinke so faire Queene, goe to thy bed,
Let not my loue be so discomforted.

sp.speaker: Wil,
sp.l: No. no, I warrant thee Iane, make hast & dispatch this
That thou maist haue another against next Christmas

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ladies attend her, Countesse of Salisburie, sister Mary
Who first brings word that Harrie hath a Son
Shall be rewarded well:

sp.speaker: Will,
sp.p:
I, Ile bee his suertie: but doe you heare wenches, shee that
brings the first tydings how soeuer it fall out lot her be sure to say the Child's like the father or els shee shall haue nothing.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Welcome Lord Bonneuet, welcome Bishop
What from our brother brings this Embassage.

sp.speaker: Bonneuet.
sp.l: Most faire commends great & renowned Hen.
We in the person of our Lord and King,
Here of your highnesse, doe intreate a League
And to reedifie the former peace:
Held betwixt the Realmes of England and of France,
Of late disordred for some pettie wrongs:
And pray your Maiestie to stay your powers;
Alreadie leuied in low Burgandie,
Which to maintaine our oaths, shall be ingadge,
And to confirme it with more surety,
He craues your faire consent vnto his loue,
And giue the Lady Mary for his Queene,
The second sister to your Royall selfe.
So may an heire springing from both your bloods.
Make both Realmes happie by a lasting league,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Wee kindely doe receiue your Maisters loue,
And yet our grant stands stronge vnto his suit,
If that no following censure feeble it:
For we herein must take our Counsels aide.
But howsoeuer our answere shall be swift,
Meane time we grant you faire accesse to woe,
And winne her (if you can) to be his Queene.
Our selfe will second you. Right welcome both,
Lord Cardinall, these Lords shall be your Guests,
But let our Treasure wast to welcome them:
Banquet them, how they will, what cheere, what sport,
Let them see Harry keepes a kingly Court:

sp.speaker: Wolsie.
sp.l: I shall my Soueraigne.
Ki With draw a while our selues will follow ye.
Now will are you not deceiu'd in this Embassage,
You heard they came for aide against the Turke.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Well then, now I see there is loud lies told in London
But als on for their comming's to as much purpose as the other:

sp.speaker: king:
sp.l: And why I pray,

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Why dost thou thinke thy sister such a foole, to marrie such an old dies veneris, he get her with Prince? I, when either I, or the Cardinall prooue Pope, and that will neuer be, I hope:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: How knowest thou him to be old, thou neuer sawest him?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: No, nor he me, but I saw his picture with ner-a toothe the head out, and all his beard as well fauoured as a white frost, but it is no matter, if he haue her, he will dye shortly, and then she may help to bury him,

sp.speaker: 1 Lad.
sp.l: Runne, Runne, good Maddam, call the Ladyes in.
Call for more Womens helpe, the Queene is sicke.

sp.speaker: 2 Lad
sp.l: For Gods loue goe backe againe, and warme more clothes,
O let the wine be well burned I charge yee.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: I, In any case, or I cannot drinke it, doost thou heare Harry, what a coile they keepe: I warrant, these women will drinke thee vp more wine, with their gossipping, then was spent in all the Conduits at thy Coronation.

div.stage: Enter Lady Mary and the Countes of Salisbury.

sp.speaker: King,
sp.l: Tis no matter Will, How now Ladies,

sp.speaker: La: Mary,
sp.p: I beseech your grace command the foole forth of the pesence,

sp.speaker: k.
sp.l: Away William you must be gone, her's womens matters in hand

sp.speaker: Willi,
sp.l: Let them speake loe then, Ile not out of the roome, sure,

sp.speaker: Count,
sp.l: Come, come let's thrust him out, he'le not sturre else:

sp.speaker: Will:
sp.p: Thrust me, nay and ye goe to thrusting, ile thrust some of you downe I warrant ye:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay, goe good William:

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ile out of their company Harry, they will scratch worse then cats, if they catch me, therefore Ile hence and leaue them, God boy Ladyes do you heare Maddam Mary, you had neede to be wary, my newes is worth a white-cake, you must play at tennis with old Saint Dennis, and your maiden-heade must lye at the stake.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Ha, ha, the foole tels you true (my gentle sister)
But to our businesse, how fares my Queene?
How fares my Iane, has she a sonne for me?
To raise againe our kingdomes soueraignty

sp.speaker: Lady Mary,
sp.l: That yet rests doubtfull, O my princely Lord.
Your poore distressed Queene lyes weake and sicke,
And be it sonne or daughter, deere she buyes it,
Euen with her deerest life, for one must dye:
All Womens helpe is past. Then good my Leige,
Resolue it quickly, if the Queene shall liue,
The Child must die, or if it life recelues,
You must your hapeles Queene of life bereaue,

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: You peirce me with your newes, run, send for helpe.
Spend the reuenewes of my Crowne for aide,
To saue the life of my beloued Queene:
How hap't she is so ill attended on.
That we are put to this extremity,
To saue the Mother or the child to dye.

sp.speaker: Countesse.
sp.l: I beseech your grace resolue immediatly,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Immediatly (saist thou) O, tis no quicke resolue
Can giue good verdit in so sad a choise:
To loose my Queene, that is my some of blisse,
More vertuous than a thowsand Kingdomes be;
And should I lose my Sonne (if Sonne it be)
That all my subiects to desire to see.
I loose the hope of this great Monarchy.
What shall I doe?

sp.speaker: Lady Marie.
sp.l: Remember the Queene my Lord:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I not forget her (Sister) O poore soule,
But I forget thy paine and miserie,

sp.speaker: Goe,
sp.l: let the Childe die; let the Mother liue,
Heauens powerfull hand may more children giue:
Away, and comfort her with our reply,
Harry will haue his Queene though thowsands die.
I know no issue of her princely wombe:
Why then should I preferre't before her life.
Whose death ends all my hopefull loyes on earth.
God's will be done, for suer it is his will,
For secret reasons to himselfe best knowne:
Perhaps he did mould forth a Sonne for me,
And seeing (that sees all) in his creation,
To be some impotent and coward spirit,
Vnlike the figure of his Royall Father:
Has thus decrede, least he should blurre out fame,
As Whylome did the sixt king of my name
Loose all his Father (the first Henrie) wonne.
Ile thanke the Heauens for taking such a Sonne.
Whos's within there?

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Goe Compton, bid Lord Seimer come to me,
The honor'd Father of my wofull Queene
Now now what newes?

sp.speaker: L. Marie.
sp.l: We did deliuer what your highnesse wild,
Which was no sooner by her grace receiud:
But with the sad report, she seemd as dead,
Which causd vs stay, after recourerie.
She sent vs backe t'intreate your Maiestie,
As euer you did take delight in her,
As you preferre the quiet of her soule,
That now is readie to forsake this life,
As you desire to haue the life of one,
She doth intreate your grace that she may dye,
Least both doth perish in this agonie:
For to behold the infant suffer death,
Were endlesse tortures, made to stop her breath,
Then to my Lord (quoth she) thus gently say,
The child is faire, the mother earth and clay,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sad messenger of woe; oh my poore Queene,
Canst thou so soone consent to leaue this life,
So pretious to our soule, so deere to all,
To yeeld the hopefull yssue of thy loines,
To raise our second comfort, well, be it so:
Ill, be it so: stay, I reuoke my word,
But that you say helpes not, for she must dye:
Yet if ye can saue both, ile giue my crowne:
Nay, all I haue, and enter bonds for more,
Which with my conquering sword with fury bent,
Ile purchase in the farthest continent,
Vse all your chiefest skill, make hast away,
Whilst we for your successe deuoutly pray.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.l: All ioy and happinesse betide my Soueraigne.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ioy be it good Lord Seymer noble father,
Or ioy, or griefe, thou hast a part in it,
Thou comit to greete vs in a doubtfull houre,
Thy daughter and my Queene lies now in paine,
And if I loose, Seymer thou canst not gaine.

sp.speaker: Sey.
sp.l: Yet comfort, good my Liege, this womans woe,
Why? tis as certaine to her as her death,
Both giuen her in her first creation:
It is a sower to sweete, giuen them at first,
By their first mother, then put sorrow hence:
Your grace, ere long shall see a gallant Prince,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Be thou a Prophet Seymer in thy words,
Thy loue some comfort to our hopes affoords,
How now.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: My gratious Lord, here I present to you,
A goodly sonne: see here your flesh, your bone,
Looke here royall Lord, I warrant tis your owne.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.l: See here my Liege, by the rood a gallant Prince,
Ha little cakebread, foregod a chopping boy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Euen now I wept with sorow, now with ioy,
Take that for thy good newes, how fares my Queene.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: O my good Lord, the wofull.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tell no more of woe, speake, doth she liue?
What? weepe ye all, nay, then my heart misgiues,
Resolue me sister, is the newes worth hearing.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.l: Nor worth the telling, royall Soueraigne.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now, by my crowne, thou dimst my royaltie,
And with thy cloudie lookes eclipst my ioyes,
Thy silent eye bewrayes a ruthfull sound,
Stopt in the organs of thy troubled spirit:
Say, is she dead.

sp.speaker: La. Mary.
sp.l: Without offence she is.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Without offence, saist thou, heauen take my soule,
What can be more offensiue to my life:
Then sad remembrance of my faire Queenes death,
Thou wofull man, that camst to comfort me:
How shall I ease thy hearts calamitie?
That cannot helpe thy selfe, how one sad minute
Hath raisd a fount of sorrowes in his eyes,
And bleard his aged cheekes, yet Seymer see,
She hath left part of her selfe, a sonne to me:
To thee a graund-child, vnto the land a Prince,
The perfect substance of his royall mother,
In whom her memory shall euer liue:
Phaenix Iana obit vato Phaenice,
Dolendum secula phaenices nulla tulisse duas.
One Phenix dying, giues another life,
Thus must we flatter our extreamest griefe.
What day is this.

sp.speaker: Cump.
sp.l: Saint Edwards euen my Lord.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Prepare for christning, Edward shall be his name,

div.stage: Enter the Cardinall, Embassadors, Bonner and Gardner.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: My Lords of Fraunce you haue had small cheere with vs,
But you must pardon vs, the times are sad,
And focits not now for mirth and banqueting:
Therefore I pray make your swift returne,
Commend me to your king, and kindly tell him,
The English Cardinall will remaine his friend,
The Lady Mary shall be forthwith sent,
And ouertake ye ere you reach to Douer:
And for the businesse that concearnes the league,
Vrge it no more, but leaue it to my care,

sp.speaker: Bone.
sp.l: We thanke your grace, my good Lord Cardinal,
And so with thankfulnesse we take our leaues.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Happily speed my honorable Lords,
My heart, I sweare, still keepes you company,
Farewell to both, pray your king remember,
My sute betwixt him and the Emperour,
We shall be thankfull, if they thinke on vs.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: We will be earnest in your cause my Lord,
So of your grace we once more take our leaues.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Againe farewell, Bonner conduct them forth,
Now Gardner, what thinkst thou of these times.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Well, that the leagues confirmd, my gratious Lord,
Ill, that I feare the death of good Queene Iane,
Will caute new troubles in our state againe.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Why thinkst thou so?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: I feare false Luther; doctrins spread so farre,
I cast that his highnesse now vnmaried,
Should match amongst that sect of Lutherans,
You saw how soone his maiestie was wonne,
To scorne the Pope, and Romes religion,
When Queene Anne Bullen wore the diadem.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Gardner tis true, so was the rumor spread:
But Woolsie wrought such meanes she lost her head,
Tush feare not thou whilst Haries life doth stand,
He shall be king, but we will rule the land.
Bonner come hither, you are our trustie friend:
See that the treasure we have gathered,
The Copes, the Vestments, and the Challices,
The smoake pence, and the tributary fees,
That English chimnies pay the Church of Rome:
Be barreld close within the inner seller,
Wele send it ouer shortly to prepare,
Our swift aduancement to Saint Peters chaire,
Be trustie, and be sure of honors speedily,
The king hath promised at the next election,
Bonner shall haue the Bishopricke of London.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: I humbly thanke your grace.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: And Gardner shall be Lord of Winchester:
Had we our hopes, what shall you not be then,
When we haue got the Papall diadem.

div.stage: Enter Brandon, Dudley, Gray, Seymer, Compton.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: How now Sir William Cumpton, where is the king.

sp.speaker: Cum.
sp.l: His grace is walking in the gallery,
As sad and passionate as ere he was.

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.l: Twere good your grace went in to comfort him.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Not I Lord Dudley, by my George I sweare,
Vnlesse his Highnesse first had sent for me,
I will not put my head in such a hazzard,
I know his anger, and his spleene too well.

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.l: Tis strange, this humor hath his highnesse held,
Euer since the death of good Queene Iane,
That none dares venture to conferre with him.

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.l: Here comes the Cardinall.

sp.speaker: Bran
sp.p: I, and two fooles after him, his Lordship is well attended still

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: Lets win this prelate to salute the king,
It may perhaps work his disgrace with him,

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: How now William, what? are you here to,

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I my Lord, all the fooles follow you, I come to bid my cosin Patch welcome to the court, and when I come to Yorke house, hele do as much for me, will yee not Patch?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Yes cosin, hey, da, tere, dedell, dey, day.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: What, are you singing sirra.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Ile make him cry as fast anon I hold a peny.

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.l: God morrow to your grace my good Lord Cardmall.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: We thanke your honour.

sp.speaker: Kyng.
sp.l: What Cumpton, Carew.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: Harke, the king cals.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Mother of God, how are we attended on: who waights without.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: Go in Sir William, and if you find his grace
In any milder temper then he was last night,
Let vs haue word, and we will visit him.

sp.speaker: Cump.
sp.l: I Will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: What is the occasion, that the kings so mou'd.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: His grace hath taken such an inward greefe,
With sad remembrance of the Queene that's dead:
That much his highnesse wrongs his state and person,
Besides in Ireland, do the Burkes rebell,
And stout Pearsie that disclod the plot,
Was by the Earle of Kildare late put to death.
And Martin Luther out of Germanie.
Has writ a booke against his Maiestie,
For taking part with proud Pope Iulius,
Which being spred by him through Christendome,
Hath thus incenst his royall maiestie.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Tush, I haue newes, my Lord, to salue that sore,
And make the king more feard through christendome,
Then euer was his famous auncestors:
Nor can base Luther with his heresies,
Backt by the proudest germaine potentate,
Heretically blurre king Henries fame:
For honour that he did Pope Iulius,
Who in high fauour of his Maiestie,
Hath sent Campeus with a bull from Rome,
To adde vnto his title this high stile:
That he and his faire posteritie,
Proclaimd defenders of the faith shall be:
For which intent the holy Cardinals come,
As Legats from the Emperiall court of Rome.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.l: This newes, my Lord, may somthing ease his mind,
Twere good your grace would go and visit him.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: I will, and doubt not but to please him well.

sp.speaker: Seym.
sp.p: So, I am glad he's in, and the king be no better pleased then he was at our last parting, hele make him repent his saucinesse.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.p: How now old William, how chance you go not to the king, and comfort him.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
No birlady, my Lord, I was with him too lately already, his fist is too heauie for a foole to stand vnder, I went to him last night,
after you had left him, seeing him chase so at Charles, here to make him merry; and he gaue me such a boxe on the eare, that stroke me cleane through three chambers, downe foure paire of staires, fell ore fiue barrels, into the bottome of the seller, and if I had not well lickard my selfe there, I had neuer liu'd after it.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: Faith Will, ile giue thee a veluet coate, and thou canst but make him merry.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Will ye my Lord, and ile venter another boxe on the eare but ile do it.

sp.speaker: Cum.
sp.l: Cleare the presence there, the king is comming,
Gods me, my Lords, what meant the Cardinall,
So vnexpected thus to trouble him.

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.l: Is the king mou'd at it.

sp.speaker: Cumpt.
sp.l: Iudge by his countenance, see he comes.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Ile not indure the storme.

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Runne foole your maister will be feld else.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Did we not charge that none should trouble vs,
Presumptuous priest, proud prelate as thou art,
How comes it you are growne so saucie sir,
Thus to presume vpon our patience,
And crosse our royall thought disturbd and vext,
By all your negligence in our estate,
Of vs and of our countries happinesse.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: My gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Fawning beast stand backe:
Or by my crowne, ile foote thee to the earth,
Wheres Brandon, Surrey, Seymer, Gray,
Where is your counsell now, O now ye crooch,
And stand like pictures at our presence doore,
Call in our guard, and beare them to the Tower,
Mother of God, ile haue the traitors heads,
Go hale them to the blocke, vp, vp, stand vp,
Ile make you know your duties to our state,
Am I a cypher, is my sight growne stale,
Am I not Hary, am I not Englands king, Ha.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: So la, now the watch words giuen, nay and hee once cry ha, neare a man in the court dare for his head speake againe, lye close cosin Patch.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Ile not come neare him cosin, has almost kild me with his countenance.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We haue bene too familiar, now I see,
And you may dally with our maiestie:
Where are my pages there.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Trusse sirra, none to put my garter on,
Giue me some wine, here stuffe a the tother side,
Proud Cardinall who follow'd our affaires in Italy,
That we that honor'd so Pope Iulius,
By dedicating bookes at thy request,
Against that vpstart sect of Lutherans,
Should by that hereticke be banded thus,
But by my George, I sweare, if Henry liue,
Ile hunt base Luther through all Germany,
And pull those seuen electors on their knees:
If they but backe him against our dignities.
Bace slaue tie soft, thou hurst my legge,
And now in Ireland the Burkes rebell,
And with his stubborne kernes makes hourely rodes,
To burne the borders of the English pale,
And which of all your counsels helpes vs now.

sp.speaker: Cumpt.
sp.l: Here's wine, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Drinke, and be dambd, I cry thee mercy Cumpton,
What the diuell mentst thou to come behind me so,
I did mistake, ile make thee amends for it,
By holy Paule, I am so crost and vext,
I knew not what I did, and here at home,
Such carefull statsemen do attend vs,
And lookes so wisely to our common weale,
That we haue ill May-dayes, and riots made:
For lawlesse rebels do disturbe our state,
Twelue times this terme, haue we in person sate,
Both in the starre chamber, and Chauncery courts,
To heare our subiects sutes determined:
Yet tis your office Woolsie, but all of you
May make a packehorse of king Henry now:
Well, what would ye say.

sp.speaker: Wool.
sp.l: Nothing that might displease your maiesty,
I haue a message from the Pope to you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then keepe it still, we will not heare it yet,
Get all of you away, auoid our presence
We cannot yet commaund our patience,
Reach me a chaire.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: Now wil, or neuer, make the king but smile,
And with thy mirthfull toyes allay his spleene,
That we his counsell, may conferre with him,
And by my Honor, ile reward thee well,
Too him good Will.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Not too fast, I pray, least will Sommers here bee seene againe, I knowe his qualities as well as the best an ye: for euer when he's angry, and no body dare speake to him, ye thrust me in by the head and shoulders, and then wee fall to buffits, but I know who has the worst ant: but go, my Lord, stand aside, and stirre not till I call yee, let my cosin Patch and I alone, and hee goe to boxing, wele fall both vpon him, thats certain: but and the worst come, bee sure the Cardinals foole shall pay fort.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Vse your best skill, good william, ile not be seene, Vnlesse I see him smile.

sp.speaker: wil.
sp.p: Where art thou cosin, alas poore foole, he's crept vnder the table, vp cosin, feare nothing, the stormes past, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.l: Is the king gon, cosin?

sp.speaker: wil.
sp.l: No, no, yonder he sits, we are all friends now,
sp.p: The Lords are gone to dinner, and thou and I must waite at the kings table.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Not I birlady, I would not waite vpon such a Lord, for all the liuings in the land, I thought he would haue kild my Lord Cardinall, he lookt so terribly.

sp.speaker: wil.
sp.p: Foe, he did but iest with him, but ile tell the cosin the rarest tricke to bee reueng'd ast passes, and ile giue thee this fine silke point and thou'lt do it.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: O braue, o brave, giue me it cosin, and ile doe what so ere tis.

sp.speaker: wil.
sp.p: Ile stand behind the post here, and thou shalt goe softly stealing behind him, as hee sits reading yonder, and when thou comst close to him, cry boh, and wele scarre him so, he shall not tell where to rest him.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: But will he not be angry?

sp.speaker: wil.
sp.p:
No, no, for then ile shew my selfe, and after he sees who tis hele
lafe and be as merie as a magge pie, and thow't bee a mayd man by it, for all the house shall see him hugge thee in his armes, & dandle thee vp and down with hand & foot an thou wert a footebal,

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: O fine come cosen, giue me the pynt first, & ile rore so lowd that ile make him beleeue that the diuels come.

sp.speaker: Will:
sp.p: So doe and feare nothing, for an thou wert the diuell himselfe, hele coniure thee I warrant thee, I would not haue such a coniuring for twentie crownes: but when he has made way, ile mak him merry enough, I doubt it not, so so now cossen looke to your Coxecomb:

sp.speaker: Page:
sp.l: Boe.

sp.speaker: Ile:
sp.l: Mother of God whats that.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Boe.

sp.speaker: King:
sp.l: Out asse take that and tumble at my feete.
For thus Ile spurne thee vp an downe the house:

sp.speaker: Pach:
sp.l: Helpe cossen helpe:

sp.speaker: Will:
sp.l: No cossen now he's coniuring. I dare not come neere him.

sp.speaker: king.
sp.l: Who set this nat'rall heere to trouble me.

sp.speaker: En, Comp:
sp.p: Whos's that stands laffing there, the foole, ha, ha, Wheres Compton. Mother a God I haue found his drift, tis the craftiest old villaine in christendome, marke good Sir William, because the foole durst not come neere himselfe, seeing our anger, sent this sillie Asse, that we might wreake our royall spleene on him: whilest hee stands laffing to behold the left, byth blessed La (Copton) Ile not leaue the foole, to gaine a million, he contents me so, come hether Will,

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ile know whether ye haue donne knocking first, my cosen pach looks pittifully, ye had best bee friends with vs I can tell you, weele scare ye out of your skin els

sp.speaker: King:
sp.l: Alas, poore pach hold sirra ther's an Angell to buy you points.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Law Cosin, did not I say he'le make much on ye,

sp.speaker: Pach:
sp.l: I cosin but has made such a singing in my head
I cannot see where I am.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: All the better cosin and your head fall a singing, your feete may fall a dauncing & so saue charges to the piper:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Wil Sommers, prethee tell me why didst thou send him first.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Because ile haue him haue the first fruits of thy furie. I knowe how the matter stood with the next that disturb'd thee, therefore I kept ith rereward, that if the battaile grew too hot, I might run presently,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But wherefore came ye.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
To make thee leaue thy mellancholly and turne merrie man againe, thou hast made all the Court in such a pittifull case as passes,
the Lords has attended here this foure daies, and none dares speake to thee, but thou art readie to choppe of their heads sort: and now I seeing what a fretting furie thou continuest in, and euerie one said twol'd kill thee if thou keepst it, pulld eene vp my heart, and vowd to loose my head, but ile make thee leaue it,

sp.speaker: Ling.
sp.l: Well William I am behoulding to ye.
Ye shall haue a new Coate and a cap for this.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Nay then, I shall haue two new coats and cap pes, for Charles Brandon promised mee one before, to performe this enterprise:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He shall keepe his word will, goe call him in,
Call in the Lords tell them our spleene is calmbd:
Mother a God we must giue way to wrath.
That chafes our Royall blood with anger thus:
And vse some mirth I see to comfort vs.
Draw neere vs Lords, Charles Brandon lift to me:
Will Sommers here must haue a Coate of you,
But Patch has earned it dearest whers the foole?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Hees enne creeping as nere the doore as he can,
Heele faine begon I see, and he could get out,
Wouldest thou not cosin?

sp.speaker: Pach:
sp.l: Yes cosin Wil. Ild faine be walking, I am afraid,
I am not as I should be:

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Come, ile helpe thee out then, dost thou heare my Lord Cardinall, your foole is in a pittifull taking, hee smells terriblie.

sp.speaker: Wools:
sp.l: You are too craftie for him William,

sp.speaker: King:
sp.l: So is he Woolsey credit me.

sp.speaker: Wil:
sp.p: I thinke so my Lord, as long as will liue, the Cardinals foole must giue way to the kings foole:

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: Well sir be quiet, and my reuerent Lords,
I thanke you for your patient suffering,
We were disturbed in our thoughts we sweare,
We now intreat you speake and we will heare,

sp.speaker: Wools.
sp.l: Then may it please your sacred Maiestie,

sp.speaker: Campe.
sp.l: Legate to his holinesse,
Attends with letters from the Court of Rome.

sp.speaker: King:
sp.l: Let him draw neere, weele giue him Audience,

sp.speaker: Dudley:
sp.l: and Gray Attend the Cardinall,
And bring

sp.speaker: Campeu:
sp.l: to our presence here:

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.l: Gray, We goe my Lord:

sp.speaker: king:
sp.l: Brandon and Seymer, place your selues by vs,
To heare this message from his holinesse,
You reuerent princes pillers of the Church:
Legats, Apostolicke, how fares the Pope,

sp.speaker: Campeus,
sp.l: In health great King and from his sacred lips:
I bring a blessing Appostolicall.
To English Henrie and his subiects all:
And more to manifest his loue to thee,
The prop and piller of the Churches peace:
And gratifie thy loue made plaine to him,
In learned books gainst Luthers heresie,
He sends me thus to greet thy Maiestie:
With stile and titles of high dignitie,
Command the Heralds and the Trumpets forth:

sp.speaker: Semer:
sp.l: Gentlemen dispatch and call them in:

sp.speaker: Will:
sp.l: Lord blesse vs, whats here to doe now,

sp.speaker: Campe,
sp.l: Receaue this Bull sent from his holinesse.
For confirmation of his dignitie
To thee, and to thy faire posteritie.

sp.speaker: Will:
sp.p: Tis well the Kings a widdower, and he had put forth your Bull with his hornes forward, Ide haue mard your message. I can tell ye.

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: Peace

sp.speaker: wil:
sp.l: Herralds attend him:

sp.speaker: Campe:
sp.l: Trumpets prepare whilst we allowd prouounce
This sacred message from his Holinesse,
And in his reuerent name I heare proclayme
Henrie the Eight by the grace of God,
King of England, France and Ireland.
And to this title, from the Pope we giue:
Defender of the faith, in peace to liue:

sp.speaker: Wools,
sp.l: Sound Trumpets, and God saue the King.

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: We thanke his holinesse for this princely fauour,
Receiuing it with thankes and reuerence:
In which whilst we haue life, his grace shall see,
Our sword defender of the faith shalbe,
Goe one of you salute the Maior of London,
Bid him with Herralds and with Trumpets sound,
Proclaime our Titles through his gouernment,
Goe Gray, see it donne, attend him fellowes:

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.l: I goe my Lord, Trumpets follow me,

sp.speaker: King,
sp.l: What more Lord Legat doth his holinesse will?

sp.speaker: Campe:
sp.l: That Henry Ioyning with the Christian Kings
Of France and Spaine, Denmarke and Portugale
would send an Armic to assaile the Turke,
That now inuades with Warre the Ile of Rhodes,
Or send twelue thowsand pound to be disposd,
As his holines thinkes best for their releife.

sp.speaker: Wils:
sp.p: I thought so, I knew twoold be a monnie matter, when als done, now thart defender of the faith, the Pope will haue thee defend euerie thing himself and all.

sp.speaker: king,
sp.l: Take hence the foole.

sp.speaker: wil:
sp.p: I, when can ye tel? dost thou thinke any oth Lords will take the foole, none here, I warrant, except the Cardinals.

sp.speaker: king,
sp.p: What a knauish fooles this, Lords you must beare with him come hether Wyll, what saist thou to this newe tytell giuen vs by the Pope, speake, ist not rare?

sp.speaker: Will:
sp.p: I know not how rare it is, but I know how deer twill bee, for I perceiue twill cost thee twelue thowsand 'pounds, at least, besides the Cardynals cost in comming.

sp.speaker: kyng,
sp.p: All these nothing; the title of defender of the faith is worth yee, twise as much, say, is it not.

sp.speaker: Wyll:
sp.p: No by my troth, dost heare old Harie; I am suer, the true faith is able to defend it selfe without thee, and as for the Popes faith (good faith's) not worth a farthing, and therefore giue him not a penny.

sp.speaker: K,
sp.p: Goe too sirra meddle not you with the Popes matters:

sp.speaker: W:
sp.p: Let him not meddle with thy matters then, for, and he meddle with thee, He middle with him thats certaine and so farewell, Ile goe and meete my little young Master Prince Edward, they say hee comes to Courte to night, Ile to horsebacke, Prethee Harie send one to hold my sturrup: shall I tell the Prince what the Pope has donne.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I and thou wilt Will, hee shall be defender of the faith too, one day.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: No, and he and I can defend our selues we care not,
For we are sure the faith can.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Lord Legat, so we reuerence Rome and you,
As nothing you demaund, shall be denied:
The Turke will we expell from Christendome,
Sending stout souldiers to his holinesse,
And mony to relecue distressed Rhoades:
So if you please, passe in to banquetting,
Goe Lords attend them, Brandon and Compton stay,
We haue some businesse to conferre vpon.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: We take our leaue.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Most hartie welcome to my reuerent Lords.
So, now to our businesse, Brandon say,
Heare yee no tydings from our sister Mary,
Since her arriuall in the Realme of France?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.l: Thus much we heard my Lord, at Cales met her
The youthfull Dolphin, and the Peeres of France:
And brauely brought her to the King at Towers,
Where he both married her, and crownde her Queene

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tis well, but Brandon and
Compion list to me,
I must imploy your aide and secrecie,
This night we meane in some disguised shape;
To visit London, and to walke the round,
Passe through their watches, and obserue the care
And speciall diligence to keepe our peace.
They say night-walkers, hourely passe the streets,
Committing theft, and hated sacriliege:
And slightly passe vnstaied, or vnpunished,
Goe Compton, goe, and get me some disguise,
This night weele see our Cities gouernment:
Brandon, doe you attend at Baynards. Castio,
Compton shall goe disguisde along with me,
Our swordes and bucklers shall conduct vs safe,
But if we catch a knock to quit our paine,
Weele put it vp, and bye vs home againe.

div.stage: Enter the Constable and Watch, Prichall the Cobler, being one baring a Lant-horne.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.l: Come neighbours, we have a straight command.
Our watches be scuerely lookt into:
Much theft and murder was committed lately,
There are two strangers, marchants of the Stillyard
Cruelly slaine, found floating on the Temmes:
And greatly are Stewes had in suspect,
As places fitting for no better vse,
Therefore be carefull and examine all,
Perhaps we may attach the murderer.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: Nay I assure yee maister Constable, those stew houses are places of much slaughter and redemption and many cruell deedes of equitie and wickednesse are committed there, for diuers good men loose both their money and their computation by them, I abiure yee; how say you neighbor Prichall?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Neighbour Capcase, I knowe you're a man of courrage, and for the merry cobler of Lune streete, tho I sit as lowe as Saint Faithes, I can looke as high as Paules: I haue in my dayes walkte to the stew as as well as my neighbours, but if the mad wenches fall to burdering once, and cast men into the Thames, I haue done with them, theres no dealing, if they carrie fire in one hand, and water ith tother.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Well maisters we are now plac'st about the Kings business.
And I know ye all sufficient in the knowledge of it,
I need not to repeate your charge againe:
Good neighbours, vse your greatest care I pray,
And if vnruly persons trouble yee,
Call and ile come: so syrs goodnight.

sp.speaker: 1 Wat.
sp.p: Godyegodnight and twentie syr, I warrant yee, yee neede not reconcile to our charge, vor some on vs has discharged the place this forty yeare I am sure. Neighbours what thinke you best to be done?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Euery man according to his calling neighbour, if the enemie come, here lyes my towne of Garrison, I set on him as I set on a patch, if he tread on this side, I vnderlay him on this side, or prick him through both sides, I yerke him, and tricke him, pare him and peece him, then hang him vp beth heeles till Sunday.

sp.speaker: 1 Wat.
sp.p: How say yee, by my faith neighbour Prichall yee speake to the purpose, for indeed neighbours, euery sencible watch-man is to seeke the best reformation to his owne destruction.

sp.speaker: 2 Wat.
sp.p: But what thinke yee neighbours, if euery man take a nap now, eth fore hand eth night, and goe to bed afterward.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: That were not a misse neither, but and youle take but euery man his pot first, youle sleepe like the man eth Moone yfaith.
Doe yee thinke neighbour, there is a man eth Moone?

sp.speaker: 1 Wat.
sp.p: I assure yee in a cleare day, I haue seente at midnight.

sp.speaker: 2 Wat.
sp.p: Of what occupation is he trow?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Some thinkes he's a shepheard, because ons dog, some saies he's a baker going to heate his ouen with a bauen ats backe, but the plaine truth is, I thinke he was a cobler, for yee know what the song sayes, I see a man eth Moone, fie man, fie, I see a man eth Moone, clowting Saint Peters shoone, and so by this reason, he should be a cobler.

sp.speaker: 1 Wat.
sp.p: By my fekins he saith true, alas, alas, goodman Dormouse hath euen giuen vp the gost already, us an honest quiet soule I warrant yee.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: It behoues vs all to be so how doe yee neighbour Darmonse?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Godspeed yee, Godspeed yee, nay and yee goe a godssleepie, name, I haue nothing to say to yee.
Lawe yee, his minds ons businesse, though he be nere so

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Come lets all ioyne with him and steale a nappe, euery man maisters to his seuerall stall.
Agreed, Godnight good neighbours.

sp.speaker: Cab.
sp.p: Nay, lets take no leaue, ile but winke a while, and see you againe.

div.stage: Enter King, and Compton, with bils on his backe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come sir William,
We may now stand vpon our guard you see,
The watch has giuen vz leaue to arme our selues,
They feare no danger, for they sleepe secure:
Goe carry those bils we tooke to Baynards Castle,
And bid Charles Brandon to disguise himselfe,
And meet me presently at Grace Church Corner,
We will attempt to passe through all the watches,
And so I take's will be an easie taske,
Therefore make haste.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: I will my Liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The watch-word if I chance to send to yee,
Is the great Stagge of Baydon, so my name shall bee.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: Inough, weele thinke on it.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: So, now weele forward, soft yonder's light,
I and a watch, and all asleepe burlady:
These are good peaceable subiects, heres none
Beckens to any, all may passe in peace: Ho sirrha.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Stand, who goes there?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: good fellow. Stands a hainous word the Kings
High way you haue bene at Noddie, I see.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: I, and the first card comes to my hand's a Knaue.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I am a Coatercard indeed.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Then thou must needs be a Knaue, for art neither King nor Queene, (I am sure) But whether goest thou?.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: About a little businesse that I haue in hand.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Then good night, prethy trouble me no longer.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why this is easie enough, heres passage at pleasure,
What wretch so wicked, would not giue faire words
After the foulest fact of Villainie?
That may escape vnseene so easily,
Or what should let him that is so resolu'd
To murder, rapine, theft, or sacriledge:
I see the Citie are the sleepie heads,
To do it, and passe thus vnexamined.
Fond heedlesse men, what bootes it for a King,
To toyle hithselfe in this high state affaires,
To summon Parhaments, and call together
The wisest heads of all his Prouinces:
Making statutes for his subiects peace,
That thus neglecting them, their woes increase.
Well, weele further on, soft here comes one,
Ile stay and see, how he escapes the watch.

sp.speaker: Black Will.
sp.p: So, how I am got within the Cittie, I am as safe as in a Sanctuarieat is a hard world, when Blacke Will, for a venture of fiue pound, must commit such pettie robberies at Mile-ende, but the plaine truth is, the Stewes from whence I had my quartaridgeas now growne too hote for me: theres some suspection of a murther lately done vpon two Marchants of the Stilliard, which indeede as farre as some fiue or sixe stabs comes too, I confesse I had a hand in. But mum-budget, all the Dogges in the towne must not barke at it. I must withdraw awhile till the heate bee ore, remooue my lodging, and liue vpon darke nights and mistie mornings. Now let me them see, the strongest watch in London intercept my passage.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Such a Fellow would I faine meete withall:
Well ouertaken syr.

sp.speaker: Blacke Will.
sp.l: Sblood come before me syr:
What a Dieull art thou?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A man at least.

sp.speaker: Black.
sp.l: And art thou valiant?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I carry a sword and a bucklerye see.

sp.speaker: Black.
sp.l: A sword and a buckler, and know not me, Not Blacke Will?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No trust mee.

sp.speaker: Blacke Will.
sp.p:
Slaue, then thou art neither Traueller, nor Purse-taker: for I tell thee, Blacke will is knowne and feared through the seuenteene Prouinces: there's not a sword
and Buckler man in England nor Europe, but has had a taste of my manhood. I am tole-free in all Citties, & the Subburbs about them: this is my Sconce, my Castle, my Cittadell, and but King Harry, God blesse his Maiestie, I feare not the proudest.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O ves, some of his guard.

sp.speaker: Blacke Wil.
sp.p: Let his guard eats beefe and be thankfull, giue me a man wil couer himself with his buckler, and not booge and the diuel come.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Me thinkes thou wert better liue at Court as I doe, King Harry loues a man, I can tell ye.

sp.speaker: Blacke Will.
sp.p: Would thou and all the men hee keepes were hangde, and ye loue not him then: but I will not change my reuenues for all his guardes wages.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hast thou such store of liuing?

sp.speaker: Blacke will.
sp.l: Art thou a good fellow?
May I speake freely, and wilt not tel the king ont?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Keepe thine owne counsell, and feare not,
sp.p: For of my faith the King shall know no more for mee, then thou telst him.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: And I tell him any thing let him hang me: but for thy selfe, I thinke if a fat purse come ith way, thou wouldest not refuse it. Therefore leaue the Court and sharke with me, I tell thee, I am chiefe commander of all the Stewes, theres not a whoore shifts a smocke but by my priuiledge, nor opens her shoppe before I haue my weekely tribute: And to assure thee my valour carryes credite with it, doe but walke with me through the streetes of London, and let mee see the proudest watch disturbe vs.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I shall be glad of your conduct syr.

sp.speaker: Black.
sp.l: Follow me then, and ile tell thee more.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.l: Stand, who goes there?

sp.speaker: Blac.
sp.l: A good fellow: come close, regard them not.

sp.speaker: 2. Watch.
sp.l: How shall wee know thee to be a good fellow?

sp.speaker: Blacke Will.
sp.l: My names Blacke Will.

sp.speaker: 1. Watch.
sp.p: Oh, God giue yee good night, good Maister Blacke William.

sp.speaker: 2. Watch.
sp.l: God boye sir, God boye,
I am glad we are so well rid on him.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Law sir, you see heres egresse enough,
Now follow me, & you shal see weele haue regresse backe againe,

sp.speaker: 1. Watch.
sp.l: Hoe comes there?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Come afore the Constable.
Wil What haue ye forgot me so soone? tis I.

sp.speaker: 2. Watch.
sp.l: O, tis M. Blacke William,
God blesse ye sir, God blesse ye.

sp.speaker: Black.
sp.l: How likst thou now?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Faith excellent: but prethe tell me, doest thou face the world with thy man-hood, that thus they feare thee, or art thou truely valiant?

sp.speaker: Blacke Will.
sp.p: Sfoote, doest thou doubt of my man-hood? Nay then defend your selfe, ile giue you a try all presently, betake yee to your tooles sir, ile teach ye to stand vpon Intergatories.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I am for ye, theres neere a man the King keepes shal refuse ye: but tell mee, wilt thou keepe the Kings Acte for fighting.

sp.speaker: Blacke.
sp.p: As ye please sir: yet because th'art his man, ile obserue it, and neither thrust nore strike beneath the knee.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I am pleasde, haue at you sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Watch.
sp.p: Helpe neighbours, O take ye to your browne Billes, call vp the Constable, heres a peece of chance-meddle ready to be committed: set on good-man Sprichall.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Ile ferke them a both sides, lye close neighbour Dormouse, keepe the kings peace, I charge ye, helpe M. Constable.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Keepe the peace, or strike them downe.

sp.speaker: Black.
sp.l: Sownes, I am hurt, hold I say.

sp.speaker: 2. Watch.
sp.p: Let them not passe nieghbours, heres bloodshed drawne vpon one of the Kings Officers.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Take away their weapons, and since you are so hot, Ile set you where you shall be coole enough.

sp.speaker: Blacke Wil.
sp.p: Sownes the Moones a wayning harlot, with the glimse of her light I lost his poynt, & mistooke my ward, had neere brocht my blood else.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: pray sir what are you?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I am the Kings man sir, and of his Guard.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: More shame you should so much forget your selfe,
For as I takte, tis parcell of your oath,
As well to keepe his peace, as guard his person:
And if a Constable be not present by,
You may as well as he, his place supply:
And seeing yee so neglect your oath and dutie,
Goe bare them to the Counter presently,
There shal yee answere for these misdemeanors.

sp.speaker: 2. Wat.
sp.l: Has broake my head syr, and furthermore it bleeds.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Away with them both, they shall pay thee well ere they come forth, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I beesech yee syr.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Neuer intreat man, we shall haue baile I doubt it not, But maister Constable, I hope youle doe me this fauour, to let one of your watchmen goe of an arrant for me, if I pay him?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: With all my heart syr, heres one shall goe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Hold thee good fellowe, heres an angell for thee, goe thy way to Baynards Castle, & aske for one Brandon, he serues the Duke of Suffolke, and tell him his bedfellow, or the great stagge of Baydon this night is clapteth Counter, and bid him come speake with me. Come Constable lets goe, syrrha make hast.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: I warrant you syr, and this be all, ide haue done it for halfe the mony: well, I must enquire for one Brandon, and tell him the great stag of Baydon is eth Counter, burlady I doubt they be both craftie knaues, and this is some watch-word betweene them: beth masse I doubt hee nere come well by his mony, hees so liberall, well ile forward.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.l: Syr William, are you sure it was at Graces-Church
His Maiestie appointed we should meete him?
We haue bin there and mist him, what thinke yee syr?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.l: Good faith I know not.
His Highnesse is too vnterous bold, my Lord
I know he will forsake himselfe in this,
Opposing still against a world of oddes.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Good faith tis true: but soft here comes one,
How now good fellow, whether goest thou?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: It lyes in my authoritie sir,
To aske you that question.
For I am one of the kings watch, I can tell ye.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Then perhaps thou canst tel vs some tydings:
sp.p: Didst thou not see a good lustie tall bigge set man, passe through your watch to night?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Yes sir, there was such a man came to our watch to to night, but none that past through, for he behaued himselfe so, that he was laid hold on quickly, and now he is forth comming in the Counter.

sp.speaker: Brandon.
sp.p: And whether art thou going?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Faith sir, has giuen me an Angel, to doe an arrande for him at Baynards Castle, to one Brandon, that serues the Duke of Suffolke: he sayes he is his Bed-fellow, and I must tell him, the great Stagge of Baydon, is eth Counter.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.p: If thine errande bee to Brandon, I can saue thee a labour, for I am the man thou lookst for, wee haue beene seeking him almost all this night: hold thee theres an Angel for thy newes, ile baile him I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: I thanke you sir: but hees not so soone baylde, as you thinke for, theres two of the Kings watch has their heads broke, and that must bee answered for, but alls won to mee, let them shuffell as they will, the Angels has flowne about to night, and two guls are light into my handes, and these ile keepe, let him get out as he can.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hoe Porter, whos's without there?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: Whats the matter now? will yee not goe to bed to night?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No trust me, twill be morning presently,
And I haue hope I shall be bailde ere then:
sp.p: I prethe if thou canst, entreate some of the prisoners to keepe me companie a paire of houres, or so: and weele spend them: ethe rouse of healthes, and all shall be my cost.
sp.l: Say wilt thou pleasure me?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: If that will pleasure ye sir, ye shall not want for company, heres I now that can tend it, they haue hunger and ease enough at all times.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: There's a couple of Gentlemen in the next roome, I prethe let them come in, and thers an Harry Soueraigne for thee.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: I thanke you sir, I am as much beholding to you, as to King Harry for it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I, I assure thee thou art.
Well M. Constable, you haue made the Counter
This night, the royall Court of Englands King:
And by my crowne I sweare, I would not for
A thousand pound t'ware otherwise.
The Officers in Citties, now I see,
Are like an Orchard set with seuerall Trees,
Where one must cherish one, rebuke the other:
And in this wretched Counters I perceiue,
Mony playes fast and loose, purchaces fauour,
And without that, nought but miserie.
A poore Gentleman hath made complaint to mee,
I am vndone (quoth he) and kept in prison,
For one of your fellows that serues the King,
Being bound for him, and he neglecting me.
Hath brought mee to this woe and miserie.
Another Cittizen there is, complaines
Of one belonging to the Cardinall,
That in his Maisters name hath taken vp
Commodities, valued at a thousand pound:
The paiment being deferde hath causde him break,
And so is quite vndone. Thus kings & Lords I see,
Are oft abusde by seruants treacherie.
But whist a whyle, here comes my fellow prisoners.

sp.speaker: 1. Prisoner.
sp.p: Wheres this bullie Grig, this lad of life, that will scowre the counter with right renish to night? Oh Sir you are welcome.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I thanke ye syr, nay weele be as great as our word, I assure yee. Heere Porter, thers mony, fetch wine I prethe: Gentlemen you cannot bee merry in this melancholy place; but heres a Lad has his heart as light as his purse. Sirra, thou art some mad slaue I thinke, a reguler companion: won that that vses to walke a nights, or so. Art thou not?

sp.speaker: 1. Pri.
sp.l: Harke ethen eare, thart a good fellow.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I am right borne I assure thee.

sp.speaker: 1. Pri.
sp.l: King Harry loues a man, and thou a woman:
Shall I teach thee some wit?
And tell thee why I met thee here?
I went and set my limbe-twigs, and I thinke
I got some hundred pound,
By a crooked measure at Coome Parke:
And now seeing there was watch layde,
And much search for suspitious persons:
I got won as honest as my selfe to arrest me,
By a contrary name, and lay me eth counter,
And here I know thayle nere seeke me,
And so when the heats ore, I am at libertie,
And meane to spend my crownes lustily:
How likst thou this my Bullie?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: An excellent pollicie.

sp.speaker: 1. Pri.
sp.l: But mum, no words: vse it for your self, or so.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: O syr, feare it not, be merry Gentlemen: Is not this wine come yet? Gods me, forget our chiefe guest, where's my sword and buckler-man? wheres Blacke will? how now man, melancholy? let not a little wipe make vs enemies, clap hands, and be friends.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: My bloods vp still.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: When tis at highest twill fall againe, come handes, hands.

sp.speaker: Blacke Wil.
sp.p: Ile shake hands with thee, because thou carriest a Sword and Buckler, yet thart not right Cauelere, thou knowst not how to vse them, thaste a heauie arme.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I a good smart stroke.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Thou cutst my head indeed, but twas no play, thou layest open enough, I could haue entred at my pleasure.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Nay I haue stout guard I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Childish to a man of valour, when thou shouldst haue borne thy Buckler here, thou lettest it fall to thy knee, thou gauest mee a wipe, but twas meere chaunce: but had we not beene parted, I had taught ye a little Schoole play I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Brandon.
sp.l: What hoe, porter: who keepes the gates there?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.l: Who knockes so fast?

sp.speaker: Compt.
sp.l: Stand by sirrah.

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: Keepe backe I say, whither wil ye presse amongst the prisoners?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Sirrah to the Court, and we must in.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: Why sir, the courts not kept eth Counter to day.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Yes when the king is there,
All happinesse betide our Soueraigne.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Sownes king Harry.

sp.speaker: 1. Pri.
sp.l: Lord I beseech thee no.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We all intreat your grace to pardon vs.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Stand vp good men: beshrew ye Brandon for discoeouering vs, we shall not spend our time so well this moneth: but theres no remedie now, the worst is this,
sp.l: The court good fellowes must be remoued the sooner,
Ye all are courtiers yet. Nay, nay, come forward,
Euen now you know we were more familiar:
You see pollicies holdes not alwayes currant,
I am found out, and so I thinke will you be:
Goe Porter let him be remoued to Newgate
This place I see is too secure for him:
Weele send you further word for his bestowin.

sp.speaker: 1. Pri
sp.l: I beseech your Grace.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Theres no grace in thee, nor none for thee:
Goe, away with him.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Sownes I shall to Tyburne presently.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Gentlemen, you that haue beene wrongde by my seruants and the Cardinals, shall giue me neerer notes of it,
sp.l: Both what they are, and how much debt they owe yee:
Send your petitions to the Court to me.
And doubt not but you shall haue remedie:
Theres fortie Angels, drinke to King Harries health,
And thinke withall, much wrong Kings men may do:
The which their maisters nere consent vnto.

sp.speaker: 2 Pris.
sp.l: God bless your Maiesty with happy life;
That thus respect; your wofull subiects griefe,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where's Black Will, nay come neerer man,
I came neerer you, though yee mislikte my play.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Beth Lord, your Maiesties the best sword and buckler man in Europe, ye lye as close to your wards, carrie your point as faire, that no Fencer comes neere ye for gallant Fence-play.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay now yee flatter me.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Foregod yee broake my head most gallantly.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I But twas but by chance ye know, but now your heads broke, you looke for a plaster I am sure.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: And your grace will giue me leaue, Ile put it vp and goe my waies presently.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Nay soft syr, the Keeper wil denie yee that priuiledge, Come hither syrrha, because ye shal know King Harrie loues a man, & I perceiue theres some mettall in thee, there's twentie Angels for thee, marrie it shall be to keepe yee in prison still, till we haue further vse for ye. If yee can breake through watches with egres and regres so valiantly, ye shal doote amongst your countries enemies.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: The wars sweet King, tis my delight, my desire, my chaire of state, create me but a tattord Corporall, and giue me some preheminence ouer the vulgar hot-shots, and I beat them not forward to as braue attempts, and march my selfe I th Vantguard, as ere carried against a Castle wall, break my head in two places more, and consume me with the mouth of a double culuering, Ile liue and dye with thee sweet King.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Twill be your best course sir, goe take him in,
When we haue need of men, weele send for him.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: God bless your maiestie, ile goe drinke to your health.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Begon: sir, keeper I thanke you for our lodging,
Nay indeed I doe, I know had ye known vs, it had bin better,
Praie tell the Constable that brought vs hither,
We thanke him, and commend his faithful seruice,
Gentlemen lets heare from you, & so God morrow,
Keeper, theres for my fees, discharge the offices:
And giue them charge that none discouer vs,
Till we are past the citie: in this disguise we came.
Weele keepe vs still, and so depart againe.
Once more God morrow, you may now report,
Your connter was one night king Henries court.
Away and leaue vs, Brandon what further newes?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: The old king of France is dead my Liege,
And left your sister Mary a young widdow.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: God forbid man, what not so soone I hope,
She has not yet bin married fortie daies:
Is this newes certaine?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Most true my Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Alas poore Mary, so soone a widdow,
Before thy wedding robes be halfe worne out:
We must then prepare black funerall garments too,
Well, weele haue her home, the league is broake:
And weele not trust her safetie with the French.
Charles Brandon, you shall goe to France for her,
See that your traine be richly furnished,
And if the daring French, braue thee in attempts
Of honour, Barriers, Tilt, and & Tarnament:
So to retaine her, bare thee like thy selfe,
An English man, dreadlesse of the prowdest:
And highly scorning lowly hardinesse

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I shall my Soueraigne, and in her honour,
Ile cast a challenge through all the court:
And dare the proudest Peere in France for her.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Commend me to the Ladie Catherine Parry,
Giue her this Ring, tell her on sunday next
She shall be Queene, and crownde at Westminster:
And Anne of Cleaue shall be sent home againe:
Come syrs, weele leaue the citie, and the counter now,
The day begins to breake, lets hye to court.
And once a quarter we desire such sport.

div.stage: Enter the Cardinall reading a letter, Bonner in his Bishops Roabes.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.l: My reuerent Lord of London,
Our trustie friend, the king of France is dead,
And in his death, our hopes are hindred:
The Emperour too, mislikes his praises,
But we shall crosse him fort I doubt it not:
And tread vpon his pompe imperiall,
That thus hath wrongde the English Cardinall.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Your graces letters by Campeus sent,
I doubt not but shall worke your full content.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.l: I that must be our safest way to worke,
Monie will make vs men, when men stand out:
The Bastard Fredericks to attaine the place,
Hath made an offer to the Cardinalls,
Of threescore thousand pound, which we will pay,
Three times thrice double, ere we lose the day.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Come cousen Willian, Ile bring yee to my Lord Cardinall presently.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I thanke yee cousen, and when you come to the court, Ile bring you to the King againe, yee knowe cousen, he gaue yee an angell.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: I but he gaue me such a blow oth eare for it, as I care not for comming Ins sight againe while I liue.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.p: How now Patch, who haue you got there? what Will Summers welcome good William.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I thanke your grace, I hard say your Lordship had made two new Lords here, and so the two old fooles are come to waite on them.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: We thanke yee William.

sp.speaker: Patch
sp.p:
Your Lordship will be wel guarded ,& we follow ye,
The Kings foole, and the Cardinalls, and we are no small fooles I assure yee.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: No indeede, my cousen Patch here is something too square to be set on your shooe, marry and youle weare him on your shoulder, the foole shall ride yee.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.p: A shrewde foole Bonner, come hither William, I haue a quarrell to you since our last ryming.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: About your faire Leman at Charlton my Lord, I remember.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: You speake plaine William.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Yee neuer knew foole a flatterer I warrant yee.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.l: Well Will, Ile try your ryming wits once more,
What say you to this?
The bells hang high, and lowd they cry, what do they speake?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: If you should dye, theres none would cry, though your neck should breake.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.p: You are something bitter William: But come on, once more I am for yee. A rod in schoole, a whip for a foole, is alwaies in season.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: A halter and a rope, for him that would be pope,
Against all right and reason.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.p: Hees too hard for me still, Ile giue him ouer, come tell me Will, what's the newes at Court?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Marry my Lord, they say the King must be married this morning.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.l: Married Will, to whom I prethee?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Why to my Lady Catherin Parry, I was once by, when he was wooing on her, and then I doubted they would go together shortly.

sp.speaker: Wol.
sp.l: Holy Saint Peter sheeld his Maiestie,
She is the hope of Luthers heresie:
If she be Queene, the Protestants will swell,
And Cranmer, Tutor to the Prince of Wales,
Will boldly speake gainst Romes Religion,
But Bishops weele to Court immediately,
And plot the downfall of these Lutherans:
You two are Tutors to the Princes Mary,
Still ply her to the Popes obedience,
And make her hate the name of Protestant;
I doe suspect that Latimer and Ridly,
Chiefe teachers of the faire Elizabeth,
Are not sound Catholickes, nor friendes to Rome,
It it be so, weele soone remoue them all.
Tis better they should dye, then thousands fall.
Come follow vs. Manet, Wil, and Patch.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Your Lords mad, till he be at the wedding, twas maruell the King stole it so secretly and nere told him ont, but alls one, if he be married, let him play with his Queene to night, and then to morrow heele call for me, there's no foole toth wilfull still. What shall we doe cousen?

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: Ile goe get the key of the wine-seller, and thou and Ile keepe a passage there to night.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: We haue but a little wit betweene vs already cousen, and so we should haue none at all.

sp.speaker: Patch.
sp.p: When our wits be gone, weele sleepe eth sellor, and lye without our wits for one night.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Content, and then eth morning weele but wet them with an other cup more, and thaile shaue like a rasor all day after. Come close good cuzze, let no bodie goe with vs, least they be drunke before vs, for fooles are innocents, and must be accessarie to no mans ouerthrow.

div.stage: Enter King, Queene Katherine, Cardinall, Semer, Dudly, Gray, Enter Cumpton, crying Hobeyes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Welcome Queene Katherine, seat thee by our side,
Thy sight faire Queene, by vs thus dignified,
Earles, Barrons, Knights, and Gentlemen,
Against yee all, weele be chiefe challenger,
To fight at Barriours, Tilt, and Turnament,
In honour of the faire Queene Katherine,

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: We thanke your highnesse, and beseech your grace,
sp.l: Forbeare such hazard of your royall person,
Without such honors is your handmaid pleasde,
Obediently to yeeld all loue and dutie,
That may beseeme your sacred Maiestie.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: God a mercie, but where are our children?
Prince Edward, Mary, and Elizabeth,
The royall Issue of three famous Queenes,
How haps we haue not seene them here to day?

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.l: They all my Liege attend your maiestie,
And your faire queene, so within the presence here.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tis well, Dudlie call Cranmer in,
He is chiefe Tutor to our Princely sonne,
For precepts that concerne diuinitie.
And here he comes, Cranmer, you must ply the Prince,
Let his wast howers be spent in getting learning:
And let those linguists for choyce languages,
Be carefull for him in their best indeuours,
Bid Doctor Tye, ply him to Musicke hard,
Hees apt to learne, therefore be diligent,
He may requite your loue when we are gone.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Our care and duty shall be had my Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We thanke yee.
I tell thee Cranmer he is all our hopes,
That what our age shall leaue vnfinished,
In his faire raigne shall be accomplished.
sp.p: Goe and attend him, how now Wil Sommers, whats the newes with you?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: I come to bid thee and thy new Queene Godmorrow. Looke to him Kate least he cozen thee, prouide ciuill Orenges enough, or heele haue a Lemmon shortly.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Godamercie Will, thout tell me then, wilt thou not?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
I and watch him too, or let him nere trust me: but doest heare Harry, because Ide have thee haue the poores prayers, I haue brought thee some petitions, the Fryers and Priests pray too, but I thinke us as children say grace, more for fashion
then deuotion, therefore the poores prayers ought to be soonest heard, because they beg for Godsake, therefore I prethee dispatch them.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Reade them Semer.

sp.speaker: Semer.
sp.p: The humble petition of the Lady Seaton, for her distressed son, that in his owne defence, vnhappily hath slaine a man.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The Lady Seaton, Gods holy mother,
Her sonne has had our pardon twise alreadie,
For two stout subjects that his hand hath slaine.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: And any had said so but thou Harry, Ide haue tolde him a lyde, hee nere kild but one, thou kildst the tother: for and thou hadst hang'd him for the first, the two last had bin aliue still.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The foole tels true, they wrong our Maiestie
That seeke our pardon for such crueltie:
A way with it.

sp.speaker: Will.
